nameVariants.name: 'St. Albert Methodist' Residential School/United Church School

desc: Edmonton IRS opened its doors to pupils in March 1924. The official opening of the school was on October 23, 1924
A 1931 Inspection Report indicates that the school had two classrooms
A 1933 Inspection Report indicates grades 1 to 8 were taught at the school

Classes in manual training for the boys and handicrafts for the girls opened in the fall of 1946. The manual training or 'shop work' class was held in a separate building called the utility building or garage. By December 1946, a third classroom in the main school building was required to alleviate the crowded conditions and the arrival of more students at the school. The date ofthe classroom opening is not known at this time; however, an inspection report dated Sept. 30, 1948 references three classrooms at the school.

A fourth classroom was opened in the main residence in the 1952-1953 school year to accommodate students from British Columbia and allow for a full-time academic program. (It was the fifth classroom at the school, as the manual training shop was counted as a classroom.)

A sixth classroom was opened January 5, 1953 in a renovated room adjacent to the manual training shop in the utility building or garage. The new classroom provided improvised accommodation for a senior class of pupils in grades 6 to 8 which had been held in the school chapel since September 1952
A Home Economics class using the existing school kitchen began in 1955. In 1956, a room was provided and a new kitchen installed to accommodate the Home Economics class.

The government began an integrated education program in 1956. For one year only, Edmonton IRS pupils in grades 7 to 9 were bused to the 'Guthrie School at Namao Airport', a school4 Yz miles away operated by the Defence Department. The start of the integration program allowed for the closure of the improvised classroom over the garage at Edmonton IRS. Instruction in Industrial Arts commenced at the school as of Sept. 1, 1956

In 1957, the government entered into an agreement with the West Jasper Place School District to allow pupils from Edmonton IRS to attend provincial public schools in Jasper Place, a residential suburb adjacent to the west end of the City of Edmonton

A 'Terminal Course Class' for students who had not progressed in the public school integration program began in 1958. The integration program with Jasper Place schools was expanded; Edmonton IRS pupils attended city classes from Grade 5 to Grade 12. The school ceased farming operations at the end of 1958. In late November, the livestock and farm machinery was sold by public auction

Edmonton IRS became a residence-only facility (hostel). All classroom instruction ceased in September 1960, including classes in Home Economics and Industrial Arts; all pupils residing at Edmonton IRS began attending public schools in Jasper Place

Edmonton IRS became a hostel for high school students. Beginning in 1962, new admissions to Edmonton IRS were limited to grades 8 to 12 Gunior and senior high school grades). Students previously enrolled in lower grades were expected to continue to attend Jasper Place schools to complete their schooling. Modernization of the school building included the provision of four well-appointed classrooms for the use of study groups under the tutelage of teacher-advisors. Old barns were removed

Recreational facilities at the school were considered inadequate; however, the government diverted money earmarked for a new gymnasium/auditorium to other building projects due to the uncertainty of the future ofEdmonton IRS

additionalInformation.notes: Rev. James Clarence Ludford, the school's Chaplain, Assistant Principal and Recreation Director, was convicted on Sept. 28, 1960, ofunlawfully committing an 'act of gross indecency with... another male person' [003354]. Charges were laid by the police as a result of an investigation initiated by Church authorities. Neither the Church nor the police would divulge to the government information which was considered confidential, such as the names ofthe children involved. The government considered the matter to have been dealt with by process of law, and subsequently considered the subject closed.

Government correspondence indicates that shortly after Mr. Ludford was discharged ofhis duties, it was discovered that 'at least one other staffmember had been involved in acts of sexual deviation,' and that the 'staff member resigned ostensibly for other reasons.' The details were not divulged to government officials

Six former staff members presented letters and sworn affidavits to the former Secretary of the IAA [Indian Association of Alberta] claiming an 'atmosphere of disharmony' was fostered by specific staff members, and that 'injustices were meted out to the children' by supervisors.

A dormitory supervisor was alleged to have demonstrated 'sadistic' behaviour against the pupils, including physical blows, derogatory language and threats. An investigation by government officials found the reports to be 'true, at least to some extent.' As a result ofthe investigation, the supervisor was warned not to resort to 'corporal punishment or any form of harsh treatment of pupils', and an assistant to the Principal was hired to supervise the supervisors and students, thus alleviating the Principal of such duties. In response to a letter from a member ofthe public, the government advised that the matter of any complaints against any staff member relative to cruelty to the children or using profanity, would be taken up with the Church authorities and the necessary remedial action taken.
A former supervisor was reported to have physically beaten pupils and threatened them with violence.

In May 1925, defective wiring was thought to be the cause of a fire that broke out in the engine room and laundry. There were no injuries to staff or children, although the lighting plant was completely ruined, the east side of chapel was badly burnt and the laundry almost completely lost.

In October 1948, some soap and detergents caught fire in the laundry room. The fire was contained and no injuries were reported, although considerable damage was done to the room and electrical wiring and $500 worth of clothing was destroyed.
In 1945, the school's potable (drinking) water was reported to have 'a slight laxative effect'
A 1949 chemical analysis ofthe water showed that it was satisfactory bacteriologically but only of'fair chemical quality'.
In 1962, a government nurse and the Jasper Place Health Unit reported many ofthe students had diarrhea and stomach cramps. The water was tested again and was found to be 'chemically unsuitable'.
Efforts were made by the government in 1946 to address unsanitary conditions at the school before students arrived for the start ofthe 1946 school year.

The problem of unsanitary washing conditions and the spread of skin disease was brought to the government's attention by school staff in 1953 and 1954. The principal and matron complained that there was only one large washing receptacle for each ofthe male and female pupils at the school.
Pupils at the school were treated for syphilis.
Alleged homosexuality among pupils from British Columbia.
Pupils being expelled for promiscuous habits and breaking the rules ofthe school by the girls letting the boys in their dormitory at night.
A male pupil left the dormitory at night by way ofthe fire escape, broke into the school by a window and went to the Girls' dormitory.
Two cases of pregnancy, both having occurred during summer vacation while the pupils were not in residence.

Church authorities were informed ofletters written by female pupils to their mothers telling of how the 'boys got into the Girl's residence at night and slept with some ofthe girls'. A group of pupils from Kitwanga, B.C., withdrew because parents were concerned about unfavourable rumours they had heard for several years about the school, including unspecified personal abuse by some ofthe other children and 'immorality' in the school.
A pupil discovered to be five months pregnant. The new principal was making arrangements with the Agency Superintendent for her care.
A female student leaving the school without permission on the weekend and having sexual contact with a man
A request from Kitwancool Band Council for the government to investigate reports that sexual relations were 'not infrequent' at Edmonton IRS.
A male student having sexual relations during the summer with a former student who became pregnant.
References to bullying at the school, and fighting amongst the boys. Principal Woodsworth stated that students found bullying were 'punished... severely'.
A complaint about a female pupil being 'treated meanly' by other girls at the school was withdrawn.

A male pupil is 'reprimanded for bullying smaller boys' and 'punished for fighting and for disrespect to staff member'. A female pupil was expelled for striking a staff member and using foul and abusive language.

The United Church Superintendent of Home Missions stated, 'We hear of corporal punishment being meted out with the buckle ends ofbelts, severe enough to raise welts on bodies; Mr. Strapp says that he has put a stop to that'.

In 1950, a pupil, in a letter dictated by the school Principal to the pupil's parents, stated that unless they sent money to the Principal, the pupil would be kept back a year in school and would be prevented from attending Alberta College.
There was a 'food riot' around Christmas 1960, apparently sparked by student unrest with the deteriorating physical plant and declining living conditions at the school.

In 1962, a former staff member was charged with theft after school officials learned that the staff member had misappropriated funds from pupils at Edmonton IRS. The former staff member was given a suspended sentence on condition ofrestitution ofthe students' money.
